page.title: 01LANDSCAPE
page.content: The land round Renfrew is extremely flat - no part is above 8 in ASI. The area consists largely of the flood plain of the River Clyde and its tributary the White Cart. Large tracts of land are still liable to flood in periods of exessive rainfall. The River Clyde is the main feature of the physical landscape. It is largely a man made waterway: embanked and canalised 200 years ago to enable the passage of shipping. Today the landscape is a mixture of townscape and farmscape. The main plantations of woodland are found around the farms to act as shelter belts.The south bank of the Clyde is becoming increasingly derelict because of declining industry and is overgrown within weeks of being abandoned, especially by the widespread willow herbs.
